awd_titl_txt: Conference: Recent advances in applications of harmonic analysis to convex geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide funding for the conference “Recent advances in applications of Harmonic Analysis to Convex Geometry”, to be held at North Dakota State University (Fargo, ND) on April 22-23, 2023. Several long-standing open problems in the area of convex geometry have recently been successfully solved using techniques from harmonic analysis. The objective of the conference is to bring together four experts in the field, who will each give a mini-course to an audience of mostly U.S. based graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. This will provide them with training in state-of-the-art methods and will open opportunities to start collaborations with more senior researchers. The majority of the funding will be used to support the participation of graduate students and early-career researchers, with priority given to women and members of other underrepresented groups. The following website will provide information about the conference: 
https://sites.google.com/ndsu.edu/recent-advances/home

The methods of Harmonic Analysis and Convex Geometry have a long history of successful interaction and have led to solutions of many long-standing problems by some of the proposed main speakers, such as the Busemann-Petty problem and, very recently, Ulam’s floating body problem, which was unsolved since the 1940s. The techniques used in these recent breakthroughs are now understood to be potentially useful to solve additional open problems, in which the four proposed speakers have an extensive record of successful research. The present conference aims to provide training in these very active areas of research for U.S. early career mathematicians. There will be a poster session for graduate students to showcase their work, and a special panel on open questions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The conference "Recent advances in applications of harmonic analysis to convex geometry" featured four speakers who are experts in convex geometry. Three of the speakers delivered a two-talk series, allowing them to explain in detail the application of analysis techniques to solve geometric problems. The fourth speaker gave one talk.

All speakers presented their most recent results, including the breakthrough proof of the long-standing Ulam's 19 problem in the Scottish Book. The solution of this problem has made it apparent that other open problems, previously considered unrelated, could be successfully resolved using similar analytic techniques. For this reason, the conference included an interactive discussion of open problems in geometry and how to attack them using harmonic analysis methods, led by the main speakers and other senior participants.

Several recent conferences in convex geometry have taken place in Europe or Canada, limiting access to early career mathematicians from the United States. As stated in the Proposal, one of the goals of our conference was to fill this need. The conference provided an opportunity for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows from the United States to learn the state of the art techniques directly from the mathematicians who developed them. Early career attendees presented their work during the poster session in a friendly and informal atmosphere. In addition, graduate students at North Dakota State University were able to interact with researchers and graduate students in their own area, a rare event for them, due to our geographical isolation.

Feedback from the participants was overwhelmingly positive. The PI had several requests from participants to organize a follow-up conference in the near future. The PI was recognized by the University through the NDSU Innovation in Learning Award, due to the nomination by local graduate students taking a graduate course in convexity taught by the PI and closely related to the conference topics.
